info.game_comments:
2008 College Championship quarterfinal game 1.
From the Kohl Center at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

jeopardy_round: PLEASE DON'T SET THE DORM ON FIRE

(1, 1).clue: After it gained its independence, Belarus adopted its own version of this basic currency

(2, 1).clue: Richard Burton played this king in "Camelot"; Tim Curry has played him in "Spamalot"

(3, 1).clue: This organization was formally born Oct. 24, 1945 with Soviet ratification of the charter

(4, 1).clue: A work from George Gershwin:"___ In Blue"

(5, 1).clue: Helium is OK, but this gas that filled the Hindenburg isn't; no containers of it in your room

(1, 2).clue: Hey mon!  Blue Mountain Peak is the highest point in this island country

(2, 2).clue: "It's alive!"  This Mel Brooks film, a "monster" hit in 1974, has been galvanized into a musical

(3, 2).clue: It's not Hillary, it's Rebecca Latimer Felton, who on Nov. 21, 1922 became the first woman to serve in this body

(4, 2).clue: Attributed to Lincoln:"The ___ is stronger than the bullet"

(5, 2).clue: Hey, chem majors!  This alliterative heater seen here is not to be used at Herringbone Hall

(1, 3).clue: Paris Opera House architect Charles Garnier also designed the world-famous casino in this town

(2, 3).clue: The website for "A Catered Affair" features this kind of album; fans share photos & memories of their own ceremonies

(3, 3).clue: An act passed by Parliament July 2, 1767 allowed duty-free exports of this to America--Party!!

(4, 3).clue: Where the Bishop of Rome lives:The Holy ___

(5, 3).clue: No re-creations in your room of this yearly event conceived by Larry Harvey & held many times in Black Rock Desert

(1, 4).clue: Thredbo & Perisher Blue are popular ski resorts in these aptly named Australian mountains

(2, 4).clue: Now a one-act musical on its own, "The Lorax" was originally part of this show based on Dr. Seuss books

(3, 4).clue: The April 17, 1722 inoculation of 2 daughters of the Prince of Wales against this made the practice widely accepted

(4, 4).clue: A Beatles tune:"___ singing in the dead of night"

(5, 4).clue: This item seen here is definitely not a university-approved dorm fixture

(1, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew indicates a map on the monitor.)  The waterway that separates South America from Antarctica is known as this passage, for an explorer who may have navigated it in 1578

(2, 5).clue: Like "Hairspray", the new musical "Cry-Baby" is based on a film by this highly unconventional director

(3, 5).clue: On Jan. 1, 1993 this republic came into being, & some of its people sought citizenship in the neighboring Czech Republic

(4, 5).clue: A poem from Keats:"The Eve of St. ___"

(5, 5).clue: No oily rag heaps; poor air circulation plus oxidation leads to this 2-word term, as Spinal Tap's drummer learned

(6, 5).clue: Next to/automatic advance to second round without having to play

(1, 1).clue: At the end of this Henry Fielding novel, the title character marries Squire Western's daughter Sophia

(2, 1).clue: This "Sicko" director's prescription is to give free health care to every American for life

(3, 1).clue: This quadrangular Kellogg toaster pastry originally came in 4 flavors & wasn't frosted

(4, 1).clue: This almost 27,000-square-mile African lake is named for a queen

(6, 1).clue: The Sony Open golf tournament takes place in January at the Waialae Country Club in this state capital

(1, 2).clue: This non-James Bond book by Ian Fleming was subtitled "The Magical Car"

(2, 2).clue: He went from directing the Aaron Burr "got milk" ad to a little film called "Transformers"

(3, 2).clue: This rectangular thick-crust pizza is not popular on the Italian island from which it gets its name

(4, 2).clue: This Swiss-French lake is also called Lac Leman

(6, 2).clue: September was the month chosen for the holiday honoring these relatives because it signified their autumn years

(1, 3).clue: Book I of this Edmund Spenser work relates the adventures of the Redcrosse Knight of Holiness

(2, 3).clue: After directing "Thank You for Smoking", Jason Reitman didn't suffer from a sophomore jinx with this feature

(3, 3).clue: "What would you do" for this ice cream bar whose name refers to the Canadian area of an 1890s gold rush

(4, 3).clue: Just past Astrakhan, the Volga flows into this inland "sea" that is actually a lake

(6, 3).clue: Since becoming a federal holiday in 1983, the holiday honoring him has occurred on his birthday, Jan. 15, only 4 times

(1, 4).clue: Squire Trelawney outfits the schooner Hispaniola & hires its crew in this 1883 tale

(2, 4).clue: These brothers escaped "The Matrix" & raced to release their new movie "Speed Racer"

(3, 4).clue: Thomas Jefferson brought this type of "iron" back from Europe & served the treats in the White House

(4, 4).clue: The Catatumbo River flows into this lake, an extension of the Gulf of Venezuela

(6, 4).clue: Symbols of spring, a lamb shank & an egg are part of the traditional plate used during this Jewish holiday

(1, 5).clue: Chapter 1 of this 1932 novel begins at the Central London Hatching & Conditioning Centre

(2, 5).clue: His first try at a "King Kong" remake was stopped, as "Mighty Joe Young" & "Godzilla" were being produced

(3, 5).clue: Birdseye invented this product that was originally sold as "herring savouries"

(4, 5).clue: Grande Isle & Isle La Motte are in this, the fourth-largest freshwater lake entirely in the U.S.

(6, 5).clue: This corp. is the engine behind the first National Train Day, May 10, 2008, remembering the golden spike of May 10, 1869

(0, 0).clue: "I never found the companion that was so companionable as solitude", he wrote in a chapter on solitude in an 1854 work
